title: 104_hr470
content: The Act may be cited as the "Northern Ireland Fair Employment Practices Act of 1995". The findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that overall unemployment in Northern Ireland is 13%, compared to 9% in the rest of the UK. Unemployment in the minority community is 22.8%, with some areas experiencing rates over 70%. The Fair Employment Commission reports that minorities are twice as likely to be unemployed. 80 US companies in Northern Ireland employ around 11,000 people. The MacBride Principles are a set of guidelines for fair employment in Northern Ireland aimed at promoting equal access to regional employment for the minority population, who face discriminatory hiring practices by some US businesses. These principles do not mandate disinvestment, quotas, or reverse discrimination. SEC. 3. RESTRICTION ON IMPORTS: An article from Northern Ireland cannot be imported into the US customs territory without documentation proving compliance with fair employment principles. SEC. 4. COMPLIANCE WITH FAIR EMPLOYMENT PRINCIPLES. SEC. 4. COMPLIANCE WITH FAIR EMPLOYMENT PRINCIPLES: US persons with branches or offices in Northern Ireland employing more than twenty people must ensure compliance with employment practices outlined in section 5 of the Act. They must submit an annual report to the Secretary demonstrating compliance. The MacBride Principles aim to increase representation of underrepresented religious groups in the workforce in Northern Ireland and ensure adequate security for minority employees. Each signatory must make efforts to achieve these goals. The MacBride Principles require signatories to protect workers from intimidation and physical abuse, prevent display of provocative emblems, and advertise job openings publicly. The MacBride Principles mandate special recruitment efforts to attract applicants from underrepresented religious groups without favoring any particular group in layoff, recall, and termination procedures. The MacBride Principles require efforts to abolish discriminatory employment criteria based on religion, such as job reservations and apprenticeship regulations that favor certain religious groups. Training programs should be developed to prepare all employees equally. The MacBride Principles call for the development of training programs to prepare minority employees for skilled jobs, the active recruitment of minority employees for advancement, and the appointment of a senior management staff member to oversee affirmative action efforts. The MacBride Principles require signatories to set up timetables for affirmative action and report progress annually to an independent monitoring agency. The MacBride Principles require signatories to set up timetables for affirmative action and report progress annually to an independent monitoring agency. SEC. 6. WAIVER OF PROVISIONS. The President can waive provisions of the Act if compliance would harm national security. Waivers must be published in the Federal Register and justified to Congress. Congress has 90 days to disapprove a waiver through a joint resolution. The President can waive provisions of the Act if compliance would harm national security, with Congress having 90 days to disapprove through a joint resolution. Resolutions in the Senate must follow specific procedures, while in the House of Representatives, a motion to consider a resolution is treated as highly privileged. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS AND PRESUMPTIONS. Definitions for this Act include the term "United States person" referring to residents, nationals, and domestic concerns, the term "Secretary" referring to the Secretary of Commerce, and the term "Northern Ireland" encompassing specific counties. A United States person is presumed to control a corporation in Northern Ireland if they own more than 50% of its outstanding voting securities. The United States person can be deemed to control a corporation, partnership, or enterprise if they beneficially own or control 25 percent or more of the voting securities, operate it under an exclusive management contract, have a majority of board members in common, or have the authority to appoint the majority of board members. The United States person can control a corporation, partnership, or enterprise by owning or controlling 25% or more of voting securities, operating under an exclusive management contract, having a majority of board members in common, or having authority to appoint the majority of board members. Additionally, control can also be established if the person has authority to appoint the chief operating officer of the entity. SEC. 8. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will be effective 180 days after enactment.
